definition: A group of cells that are similar in structure and perform a common function.
The microscopic study of the structure and function of tissues.
Covers body surfaces, lines internal organs and cavities, and forms glands.
Supports, binds, and protects other tissues and organs; includes bone, blood, and cartilage.
Composed of cells that have the ability to contract and generate force for movement.
Contains neurons and neuroglia; responsible for transmitting nerve impulses.
Structures that connect the cell membranes of adjacent cells, such as tight junctions, desmosomes, and gap junctions.
A type of intercellular junction where adjacent cell membranes fuse, preventing the passage of substances between cells.
A type of intercellular junction that acts like a 'spot weld' to hold cells together, providing mechanical strength.
An intercellular junction with tubular channels that allow direct communication between the cytoplasm of adjacent cells.
A single layer of flat cells that facilitates diffusion and filtration; found in air sacs of lungs and capillaries.
A single layer of cube-shaped cells involved in secretion and absorption; lines kidney tubules and glands.
A single layer of elongated cells; functions in protection, secretion, and absorption; lines the uterus and digestive tract.
Tiny, finger-like projections on epithelial cells that increase surface area for absorption.
A specialized epithelial cell that secretes mucus to protect and lubricate surfaces.
Appears layered due to nuclei at different levels but is a single layer; often ciliated; lines respiratory passages.
Multiple layers of flat cells that protect underlying tissues; forms the outer layer of skin and lines cavities.
The process where cells fill with keratin protein, die, and form a tough, protective layer.
Specialized to stretch; lines the urinary bladder and ureters.
Composed of cells specialized to produce and secrete substances into ducts or body fluids.
A gland that secretes its products into ducts that open onto surfaces.
A gland that secretes hormones directly into the bloodstream.
Secretes products by exocytosis without losing cellular material; includes salivary and sweat glands.
Loses small portions of its cell bodies during secretion; examples include mammary glands.
Releases entire cells filled with secretory products; an example is sebaceous glands.
The most common type of fixed cell in connective tissue; produces fibers by secreting proteins.
A wandering cell specialized for phagocytosis; clears foreign particles from tissues.
A large cell near blood vessels; releases heparin to prevent blood clotting and histamine to promote inflammation.
Thick, thread-like fibers with great tensile strength; found in tendons and ligaments.
Composed of elastin protein; stretchy and flexible fibers found in vocal cords and air passages.
Thin collagen fibers forming delicate supportive networks in tissues like the spleen.
Forms delicate, thin membranes; binds skin to underlying organs and fills spaces between muscles.
Stores fat, insulates, and cushions organs; found beneath the skin and around kidneys and heart.
Contains closely packed collagen fibers; forms tendons and ligaments; poor blood supply slows healing.
Thicker, interwoven collagen fibers; found in the dermis and provides strength in multiple directions.
A rigid connective tissue providing support and frameworks; cells are chondrocytes in lacunae.
Most common type; has fine collagen fibers; found on ends of bones, nose, and respiratory passages.
Contains elastic fibers; provides flexible framework for the external ear and parts of the larynx.
Very tough with many collagen fibers; acts as a shock absorber in intervertebral discs and knees.
Most rigid connective tissue; supports and protects; contains mineral salts and collagen.
A mature bone cell located in a lacuna within the bone matrix.
Connective tissue composed of cells suspended in plasma; transports substances throughout the body.
Lines body cavities not open to the outside; secretes serous fluid for lubrication.
Lines cavities and tubes open to the outside; secretes mucus for protection.
Another term for skin; covers the external surface of the body.
Composed entirely of connective tissue; lines joint cavities and secretes synovial fluid.
Voluntary muscle attached to bones; striated with multiple nuclei.
Involuntary muscle found in walls of hollow organs; spindle-shaped cells without striations.
Found only in the heart; involuntary, striated, branched cells connected by intercalated discs.
A nerve cell that senses changes and transmits nerve impulses; composed of dendrites, a cell body, and an axon.
Supporting cells in nervous tissue; nourish neurons and help with signal transmission.
